channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rail Crossing Warnings Are Sought for Mapping Apps
item.media:description: A Metrolink train after colliding with a truck whose driver followed his smartphone’s directions onto the tracks in February 2015 in Oxnard, Calif.
item.media:credit: Don Kelsen/Los Angeles Times, via Getty Images
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board asked tech companies to add the locations of grade crossings into digital maps and to provide alerts for drivers.
item.dc:creator: DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: Forgers Use Fake Web Users to Steal Real Ad Revenue
item.media:description: Michael Tiffany, center, chief executive of the computer security firm White Ops, said of a Russian cyberforgery ring: “Our adversaries are bringing whole new levels of innovation to ad fraud.”
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times
item.description: Russian cyberforgers are diverting as much as $5 million in revenue a day as part of a scheme to show video ads to fake internet users.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: European Officials Accuse Facebook of Misleading Them on WhatsApp Deal
item.media:description: The Facebook stand at the technology conference Web Summit in Lisbon in November. In August, the company said that it would start sharing some people’s data with its WhatsApp unit.
item.media:credit: Patricia De Melo Moreira/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The charges come amid growing tension between the social media company and Europe’s policy makers over how it dominates much of the region’s digital world.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Japanese Mogul Starts on Vow to Trump to Create 50,000 U.S. Jobs
item.media:description: Masayoshi Son of Softbank after a meeting with President-elect Donald J. Trump in early December.
item.description: A $1.2 billion investment by Masayoshi Son’s conglomerate, SoftBank, is the first step in his promise made in a meeting with Mr. Trump to create thousands of jobs in the United States.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: An Autonomous Car Future Needs Better Maps
item.description: The National Transportation Safety Board is urging companies to show grade crossings on the digital maps used by humans — and, one day, robots — for navigation.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: Book Deal for Pantsuit Nation, Facebook Page Supporting Hillary Clinton
item.media:description: Members of the secret Facebook group Pantsuit Nation gathered in front of the White House to take pictures and show support on Election Day for Hillary Clinton.
item.description: The group was started in late October by a 33-year-old woman. The book will maintain the random feel of scrolling through a Facebook feed.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDRA ALTER

item.title: Itineraries: Communal TV Screens in a Binge-Watching Age? Won’t Do, Airlines
item.media:description: David Dicko, chief executive of SkyLights, with the headset his company provides for onflight virtual reality experiences.
item.media:credit: Brian L. Frank for The New York Times
item.description: Tech companies are working with carriers worldwide to bring modern entertainment options to aircraft, including 3-D movies and high-speed streaming.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: No Special Perks on Snapchat for Celebrities
item.media:description: From left, an image from Kevin Hart’s Snapchat account, the Snapchat app on Jay Sean’s phone and an image from Serena Williams’s account.
item.description: Social media companies have always courted celebrities and their big followings. But on Snapchat, being famous isn’t so remarkable.
item.dc:creator: JIM KERSTETTER

item.title: Tech Tip: Give the Windows 10 Start Menu a Classic Look
item.description: Microsoft’s redesign of the Windows desktop has frustrated some longtime users, but utility software can provide a refreshing blast from the past.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Google Wants Driverless Cars, but Do We?
item.description: With a push from the tech industry and others, automated vehicles are getting the green light without yielding to public interest.
item.dc:creator: JAMIE LINCOLN KITMAN

item.title: Bits: A World of Surveillance Doesn’t Always Help to Catch a Thief
item.media:description: A security camera on the side of a building in Manhattan.
item.description: A reporter’s credit card was stolen, so he counted all the video cameras in stores where it was used afterward. And then he included the data from the Uber rides.
item.dc:creator: QUENTIN HARDY

item.title: Snapchat Plays Hard to Get With Celebrities and Influencers
item.media:description: Jay Sean, a musician, was courted by social networks like Facebook, but Snapchat has kept its distance.
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.description: While most social networking services court and elevate celebrities, Snapchat treats them like everyday users.
item.dc:creator: KATIE BENNER and SAPNA MAHESHWARI

item.title: Bits: Farhad’s and Daisuke’s Week in Tech: Is Google’s Waymo Way Better?
item.media:description: At Wednesday’s meeting with President-elect Donald J. Trump: from left, Larry Page of Alphabet, Sheryl Sandberg of Facebook, and Vice President-elect Mike Pence.
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times
item.description: Facebook fights fake news, and Google picks a funny name for its car business.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO and DAISUKE WAKABAYASHI

item.title: Corner Office: Yuchun Lee of Allego: The Value of a Daily Mistake
item.description: The chief executive, whose entrepreneurial spirit dates to kindergarten, looks for employees whose eyes sparkle and who are not set in their ways.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BRYANT

item.title: Free Cash in Finland. Must Be Jobless.
item.media:description: Factory lights glowing in Oulu, Finland, where the unemployment rate now sits above 16 percent, more than double the national average.
item.media:credit: Janne Körkkö for The New York Times
item.description: Finland will soon hand out cash to 2,000 jobless people, free of bureaucracy or limits on side earnings. The idea, universal basic income, is gaining traction worldwide.
item.dc:creator: PETER S. GOODMAN

item.title: How a Putin Fan Overseas Pushed Pro-Trump Propaganda to Americans
item.media:description: James Dowson, a far-right political activist, ran a constellation of websites out of the United Kingdom.
item.description: With the explicit aim of getting Donald J. Trump elected, a website run by a far-right activist pumped out anti-Hillary Clinton hoaxes and drew tens of thousands of views.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McINTIRE

item.title: First Words: Who’s Responsible When Extremists Get a Platform?
item.description: Social media companies aren’t just an open marketplace for ideas — they’re also amplifying the most dangerous ones.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HERRMAN

item.title: Feature: The Great A.I. Awakening
item.description: How Google used artificial intelligence to transform Google Translate, one of its more popular services — and how machine learning is poised to reinvent computing itself.
item.dc:creator: GIDEON LEWIS-KRAUS

item.title: The Haggler: Look Who’s Talking: The Previously Silent Conn’s
item.description: With a new C.E.O., a company that had remained steadfastly mum in the face of complaints now shows an openness to discussing them.
item.dc:creator: DAVID SEGAL

item.title: Vine, the Six-Second Video App, Is Not Quite Shutting Down
item.description: The app owned by Twitter will not survive but a new, pared-down version in January will allow users to share short videos to that social network.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Bits: Daily Report: Facebook Joins Fight Against Fake News
item.media:description: This image provided by Facebook shows some ways the company is trying to curb the spread of fake news.
item.description: Trying to walk a careful line of neutrality, the social network announced measures to fight fake news on the site, including partnering with groups that can help fact-check articles.
item.dc:creator: PUI-WING TAM

item.title: In Shadow of Amazon, European Challenger Looks to China for Inspiration
item.media:description: Zalando’s first custom-built logistics warehouse, in Erfurt, Germany. Orange boxes filled with designer dresses and shoes move along miles of conveyor belts in a warehouse the size of 18 football fields.
item.media:credit: Phil Moore for The New York Times
item.description: Few companies have been able to keep Amazon at bay after it decides to target a new market. Zalando, Europe’s biggest online fashion retailer, is the latest to try.
item.dc:creator: MARK SCOTT

item.title: Uber Defies California Regulators With Self-Driving Car Service
item.media:description: A self-driving Uber vehicle. Over California regulators’ objections, the company is testing the vehicles without obtaining state permits, as companies like Google and Tesla have done.
item.description: Uber said it had no intention of ending a new test of its self-driving vehicles in San Francisco, even though the state said it was illegal.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Streaming: Why Netflix Lets Movie Lovers Down, and What to Do About It
item.media:description: From left, Caleb McLaughlin, Finn Wolfhard, Millie Bobby Brown and Gaten Matarazzo in “Stranger Things.”
item.description: Sure, there’s choice via streaming. But, really, how much?
item.dc:creator: GLENN KENNY

item.title: App Smart: 2016 in Review: The Year’s Best Apps
item.media:description: NPR One is a one-stop shop for radio and audio content.
item.description: A news curator based on what friends are reading, an easy-to-access universe of NPR audio, and an upgraded beer-tracking app are among our top picks.
item.dc:creator: KIT EATON

item.title: Tech Tip: Choosing a Child’s First Smartphone
item.description: Both Android and iOS have parental control features and apps to help parents manage their offspring’s mobile experience.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Tech Tip: How to Back Up Your Social Media Feeds
item.description: If you don’t want to risk losing your photos and other memories stored online, consider making a copy of your account’s contents for safekeeping.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Tech Tip: The Quest for Your Dream Streamer
item.description: The wide array of available video-streaming devices can be overwhelming, but a bit of research will help you figure out what features you really need.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER

item.title: Tech Tip: The Twitter Post, Take 2
item.description: The popular service currently doesn’t let you edit your thoughts after you post them, but some apps can help you make corrections more quickly.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER
